awd_titl_txt: EAGER: BRAIDING: Demonstration of Topological Qubits Using Non-Abelian Anyons in the Fractional Quantum Hall Effect
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Abstract: There is a demand for a fault-tolerant implementation of quantum information processing that is immune from mistakes that occur during the course of computation. Such an information processor may be built using topological materials as a computing platform. The goal of this project is to demonstrate such a computing platform using states that have been predicted in certain semiconductor devices that realize a unique form of a quantum phenomenon called fractional quantum Hall effect, leading to topological qubit. A successful development of topological qubit can help revolutionize the field of quantum computation and produce a significant speed up of certain types of computations such as an efficient database search and simulation of quantum systems. The research project will help train a new generation of students on the concepts and techniques of an emerging frontier of quantum science. 

Technical abstract: Topological quantum computing is a potentially enabling technology that has emerged from study of condensed matter physics in recent years. The fractional quantum Hall effect (FQHE), realized in high quality semiconductor structures at low temperatures and high magnetic fields, is a promising template for realization of topological qubit. Quantum information in a topological qubit is stored in non-Abelian anyons which have been predicted for the FQHE states that occurs at 5/2 filling factor. Demonstration of topological qubits based on braiding of non-Abelian anyons of the 5/2 FQHE state is proposed. The goal is to advance the experimental techniques for detection and measurement of low energy excitations that lies at the heart of this emerging paradigm. A successful measurement of the statistical phase angle of anyonic excitations of the FQHE liquids in electronic Fabry-Perot interferometers fabricated from high mobility GaAs/AlGaAs heterostructures will set the stage for the demonstration of topological qubit. A successful demonstration of the logical gates will establish the protected topological qubit in these systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Topological quantum computing is an emerging new technology that leverages advances made in disparate fields such as topological field theory, semiconductors, and quantum information processing. From a purely scientific point of view, interest in topological quantum computation derives from its unique feature of topological protection, i.e. its built-in robustness against many types of errors that are detrimental to a quantum computer. Such fault-tolerance of a topological quantum computer makes it a highly desirable way of building a quantum computer. In contrast to the qubits in conventional quantum computers, information in a topological qubit is stored in non-Abelian quasiparticles. Non-Abelian anyons are exotic quantum mechanical particles. Unlike bosons and fermions, exchange of non-Abelian anyons produces a noncommutative transformation of underlying degenerate states, meaning that they retain a memory of how they were moved in the past. The defining property of anyons is that the transformation of their quantum state depends only on the topology of their exchange trajectories called braids. Non-Abelian anyons have been postulated as the elementary excitations of a fractional quantum Hall effect (FQHE) states that occur at 5/2 filling factor in a two-dimensional semiconductor heterojunction under the conditions of low temperatures and high magnetic field. Since there is no convincing experimental evidence of non-Abelian materials to date, an essential part of any research on topological qubit involves detection and demonstration of non-Abelian anyons. A successful detection of the non-Abelian anyons will also demonstrate that a realization of topological qubit may be possible.

 

We have performed quantum interference experiment in the FQHE regime to detect the non-Abelian anyons. Experimental geometry consists of an electronic Fabry-Perot interferometer (see inset of Fig. 1), an interference loop is formed with the edge-state trajectories and the inter-edge tunneling at the split-gated constrictions. Resulting interference signal contains a phase term due to Aharonov-Bohm effect and a statistical term due to braiding of an anyonic quasiparticle traversing the loop around other anyons in the center of the interferometer cavity. We demonstrate that an unambiguous Aharonov-Bohm regime can be established. Aharonov-Bohm regime is important because idealized interference phenomena can be observed without the complication of electron-electron interaction. The results of the interference experiment in the Aharonov-Bohm regime generally support the theories of non-Abelian interference envisioned for the FQHE at 5/2 filling factor. Next stage of the experiment is to carry out further investigation of the non-Abelian FQHE state. The data analysis is currently on-going and will be published in a peer-reviewed journal.

 

To date one graduate and undergraduate students have participated in the research. They received training in sample processing, experimental measurements, theories of fractional quantum Hall effect and topological quantum computing, data analysis, and programming skills. They have joined a private sector firm and are currently working on development of artificial intelligence software.


Last Modified: 12/11/2024
Modified by: Woowon Kang
